refined_goal: Build an Embodied Course Synthesizer that converts any rights-cleared tutorial video into a physics-validated, code-augmented, conversational microâ€‘course in under 15 minutes. The pipeline: ytâ€‘dlp sources video and metadata; ESPnet transcribes and diarizes; LosslessCut logic segments procedural steps; Ollama hosts onâ€‘device LLMs (e.g., llama3.1:8bâ€‘instruct + qwen2.5â€‘coder) to extract action graphs and generate assessments; Genesis replays the extracted procedure in simulation to verify feasibility; PyTorch Lightning fineâ€‘tunes domain adapters; freeCodeCampâ€™s curriculum model packages interactive tasks; React+Axios delivers the course; Huginn orchestrates agents; Harness runs content CI; pandas manages datasets; optional WeChat delivery via chatgptâ€‘onâ€‘wechat. Success: <15m ingestionâ†’course, â‰¥85% stepâ€‘toâ€‘sim fidelity, <8% WER, â‰¥20% learning gain in A/B tests. Why it matters: it turns the worldâ€™s procedural knowledge stream into safe, handsâ€‘on labs grounded in physicsâ€”not just text.
repository_synergy:
THE INSIGHT: Tutorial videos are tacit knowledge compressed into noisy narratives. LLMs can propose plans from them, but lack grounding; simulators can verify actions but donâ€™t know what to simulate. The hidden bridge is to treat video â†’ plan â†’ simulation â†’ assessment as a closed control loop, where each component injects constraints the others canâ€™t selfâ€‘generate. The aha: use Genesis as a critic for languageâ€‘derived procedures, and use videoâ€‘derived timing to constrain the simulator. That creates a selfâ€‘correcting pipeline that turns demonstrations into interactives.

WHY THESE REPOS: ytâ€‘dlp is not just a downloaderâ€”itâ€™s a highâ€‘fidelity metadata harvester (chapters, descriptions, formats) powering step detection. LosslessCut encodes a philosophy: edits without recompression, segment by keyframe/peakâ€”repurposed as headless ffmpeg heuristics to align action boundaries with ASR. ESPnet brings stateâ€‘ofâ€‘theâ€‘art ASR/TTS and diarization to extract roleâ€‘specific imperatives (â€œnow tighten the screwâ€). Ollama offers local, swappable models with lowâ€‘latency token streaming and a standard REST APIâ€”crucial for reproducible, offline course builds. Genesis is the rare physics engine designed for largeâ€‘scale programmatic experimentsâ€”perfect for verifying the physical plausibility of a languageâ€‘extracted procedure graph. PyTorch Lightning lets us fineâ€‘tune lightweight adapters (ASR domain lexicons, actionâ€‘classifier heads) without boilerplate. freeCodeCamp contributes a schema for lessons, hints, and tests so we can package outputs as credible curricula. React + Axios provides a composable client for progressive disclosure (watch â†’ simulate â†’ code). Huginnâ€™s agents turn the pipeline eventâ€‘driven (topic triggers, ingestion alarms), while Harness makes content a firstâ€‘class CI artifact (courses are versioned builds). pandas stitches datasets: segments, embeddings, error traces. chatgptâ€‘onâ€‘wechat is a social surface for regions where chat first beats web first. javascriptâ€‘algorithms offers canonical solutions and test harnessesâ€”repurposed as autoâ€‘validators for generated coding tasks.

THE SYNERGY: The illicit connection is letting a physics simulator grade an LLMâ€™s plan, and letting video timing discipline the simulator. ESPnet pulls the who/what/when from speech; LosslessCutâ€‘style heuristics create clipâ€‘level alignment; Ollama drafts a structured action graph (tools, forces, constraints); Genesis attempts the plan and emits counterexamples when physics disagrees (torque insufficient, collisions, unreachable pose). Those counterexamples are fed back to Ollama to repair the plan with concrete numeric constraints. The repaired plan yields assessments: multipleâ€‘choice grounded in failure modes, and code tasks backed by javascriptâ€‘algorithms tests. freeCodeCamp packaging transforms this into a shareable course while Harness ensures quality gates (WER, simâ€‘fidelity) pass before publish. Huginn keeps it alive: when a topic trends, a new course builds automatically.

THE INNOVATION: We stop treating LLM outputs as final and treat them as hypotheses subject to physics and audioâ€‘timed evidence. Combining local LLMs (Ollama), programmatic simulation (Genesis), and zeroâ€‘reencode segmentation (LosslessCutâ€™s strategy) yields a system that synthesizes interactive, verifiable learning from the stream of the webâ€”without cloud lockâ€‘in or brittle scraping tricks.
technical_architecture:
Data flow
1) Discovery & rights: Huginn TopicAgent watches trends/feeds; only rightsâ€‘cleared URLs pass. It emits IngestRequested(topic, url).
2) Ingest: ytâ€‘dlp Python service downloads video+captions+chapters+thumbnails; stores to object storage (e.g., S3â€‘compatible). Metadata normalized to pandas DataFrame.
3) Speech & segmentation: ESPnet ASR service produces transcript + wordâ€‘level timestamps + speaker turns. A headless cutter service (ffmpeg, guided by LosslessCut heuristics: silence detection + keyframe proximity) proposes segments aligned to imperative phrases. Output: segments.json, waveform indices.
4) Plan extraction: Ollama REST (/api/generate) with llama3.1:8bâ€‘instruct parses transcript+segments into an Action Graph: nodes(action, tool, params, time window), edges(depends_on). Qwen2.5â€‘coder in Ollama emits unitâ€‘tested coding challenges aligned to algorithmic motifs detected via keywords and mapping against javascriptâ€‘algorithms inventory.
5) Physics verification: Genesis microservice loads canonical assets (tools/parts). It attempts to execute action nodes respecting time windows (from video). It returns SimTrace (poses, forces, collisions) and a ViolationSet. If violations occur, a RepairPrompt with numeric diagnostics goes back to Ollama for parameter refinement.
6) Packaging: A Builder compiles assets into a freeCodeCampâ€‘compatible curriculum JSON (lessons, hints, tests), embeds React components for sideâ€‘byâ€‘side: video segment, live Genesis viewport (WebRTC/stream), and code editor. Axios fetches lesson JSON from the Builder API.
7) CI/CD & gating: Harness pipelines run unit tests (javascriptâ€‘algorithms), quality gates (WER < 8%, simâ€‘fidelity â‰¥ 85%, planâ€‘repair â‰¤ 3 loops). On pass, publish to catalog. Versioned artifacts tracked via Git LFS or registry.
8) Delivery: React frontend serves web users. chatgptâ€‘onâ€‘wechat bot mirrors lessons with text/video snippets and inline quizzes; Huginn routes user progress signals to analytics.

APIs and interfaces
- ytâ€‘dlp: Python API with postprocessors; expose /ingest POST {url} â†’ job id.
- ESPnet: /asr POST {audio_uri} â†’ {transcript, timestamps, speakers}.
- Cutter: /segments POST {transcript, audio_uri} â†’ segments.json.
- Ollama: /api/generate with system/tooling prompts; models: llama3.1:8bâ€‘instruct (planning), qwen2.5â€‘coder (code), mixtralâ€‘8x7b (fallback).
- Genesis: /simulate POST {action_graph, assets} â†’ {SimTrace, Violations}.
- Builder: /course PUT {metadata, assets} â†’ courseId; /course/:id GET.
- Harness: pipeline triggers via Webhook on course build; status back to Huginn.

Challenges and solutions
- Alignment drift: combine ASR timestamps with visual cuts; penalize segment boundaries that split imperative clauses; DP optimization chooses boundaries minimizing a composite loss.
- Sim realism vs latency: use coarse physics for draft (lower substeps), promote to fine only if violations persist; cache assets and compiled scenes; run Genesis headless with GPU batch.
- LLM hallucination of tools: tool set constrained by transcript keywords + chapter descriptions; reject actions referencing unseen tools.
- Evaluation leakage in code tasks: tests generated then mutated against canonical solutions from javascriptâ€‘algorithms to ensure nonâ€‘triviality; Harness fuzzing pass checks for shortcut patterns.
- Privacy/offline: Ollama and ESPnet run locally; no thirdâ€‘party APIs required.

Nonâ€‘obvious optimizations
- Use pandas to store a segmentâ€‘graph index (Parquet) enabling vectorâ€‘free retrieval by time/role/tool. 
- Preâ€‘warm Ollama with speculative decoding (short context windows) for repair loops.
- Leverage LosslessCutâ€™s spirit: prefer smart GOPâ€‘aligned cuts to avoid reâ€‘encode; we keep original quality for teaching clarity.
expected_impact:
- Makerâ€‘toâ€‘Robot Labs: A DIY furniture assembly video becomes an interactive robotics lab. Learners adjust torque/sequence in Genesis to avoid overâ€‘constraint detected by the simulator, then answer quizzes built from real failure traces.
- Field Ops Safety Refreshers: Drone battery swap videos convert into microâ€‘courses with physicsâ€‘verified steps (safe prop stop, magnetic latch order). Violations generate targeted MCQs tied to exact timestamps.
- Languageâ€‘grounded Coding Katas: When a tutorial mentions â€œdynamic programming for path planning,â€ the system issues a matched code task using javascriptâ€‘algorithmsâ€™ test harness, plus a Genesis scenario showing why suboptimal choices cause longer paths.
- Multilingual Howâ€‘To Compression: ESPnet builds bilingual transcripts; Ollama composes languageâ€‘aware hints; WeChat bot serves regions where web is secondary. Stable local inference enables offline classrooms.
- Compliance That Isnâ€™t Boring: Lockoutâ€‘tagout videos become scenario checks; learners must achieve a noâ€‘voltage state in Genesis before the quiz unlocks. Harness assures each course meets sim fidelity gates before deploy.
- Rapid Incident Debriefs: A new tool recall appears; Huginn triggers ingestion of official guidance video; 30 minutes later a validated microâ€‘lesson is live with measured torque/sequence corrections.
- Research Workflow: Instructors upload lab demos; Lightning fineâ€‘tunes ASR domain vocab; pandas provides cohort analytics on which action nodes cause confusion, informing targeted remediations.

Limitations and mitigations
- Asset scarcity: If Genesis lacks models, we proxy with simplified primitives and flag lower confidence.
- Noisy videos: High WER inflates plan errors; we surface a humanâ€‘inâ€‘theâ€‘loop transcript editor.
- Legal constraints: Only ingest content with explicit rights; Huginn includes license filters and manual approvals.
- Hardâ€‘toâ€‘simulate tasks: For soft/fluids, we switch to guidance mode (no hard gating) but still ground timing and safety checks.
innovation_analysis:
Innovation score: 9/10. The unconventional core is using a physics engine as a grading oracle for LLMâ€‘extracted procedures, driven by videoâ€‘timed constraints, then packaging outcomes into a credible curriculum with CI gates. It repurposes tooling in orthogonal domains: downloader as evidence harvester, lossless editor as alignment engine, CI as course QA.

Next steps
- Prototype minimal slice on one category (e.g., furniture assembly): 5 videos â†’ 5 microâ€‘courses.
- Implement Planâ†’Simâ†’Repair loop with two Ollama models and a single Genesis scene.
- Build React lesson shell and freeCodeCamp exporter.

Key metrics
- Build time per course; repair loops per course; sim fidelity vs. human rubric; WER; assessment discrimination index; learner timeâ€‘toâ€‘mastery.

Essential tools
- Dockerized services (ytâ€‘dlp, ESPnet, Ollama, Genesis), ffmpeg, PyTorch Lightning, Harness pipelines, Huginn event bus, React+Axios, pandas for dataops.

[![YT-DLP](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/master/.github/banner.svg)](#readme) [![Release version](https://img.shields.io/github/v/release/yt-dlp/yt-dlp?color=brightgreen&label=Download&style=for-the-badge)](#installation "Installation") [![PyPI](https://img.shields.io/badge/-PyPI-blue.svg?logo=pypi&labelColor=555555&style=for-the-badge)](https://pypi.org/project/yt-dlp "PyPI") [![Donate](https://img.shields.io/badge/_-Donate-red.svg?logo=githubsponsors&labelColor=555555&style=for-the-badge)](Maintainers.md#maintainers "Donate") [![Discord](https://img.shields.io/discord/807245652072857610?color=blue&labelColor=555555&label=&logo=discord&style=for-the-badge)](https://discord.gg/H5MNcFW63r "Discord") [![Supported Sites](https://img.shields.io/badge/-Supported_Sites-brightgreen.svg?style=for-the-badge)](supportedsites.md "Supported Sites") [![License: Unlicense](https://img.shields.io/badge/-Unlicense-blue.svg?style=for-the-badge)](LICENSE "License") [![CI Status](https://img.shields.io/github/actions/workflow/status/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/core.yml?branch=master&label=Tests&style=for-the-badge)](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/actions "CI Status") [![Commits](https://img.shields.io/github/commit-activity/m/yt-dlp/yt-dlp?label=commits&style=for-the-badge)](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/commits "Commit History") [![Last Commit](https://img.shields.io/github/last-commit/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/master?label=&style=for-the-badge&display_timestamp=committer)](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/pulse/monthly "Last activity")
yt-dlp is a feature-rich command-line audio/video downloader with support for [thousands of sites](supportedsites.md). The project is a fork of [youtube-dl](https://github.com/ytdl-org/youtube-dl) based on the now inactive [youtube-dlc](https://github.com/blackjack4494/yt-dlc).

# Ollama Get up and running with large language models. ### macOS [Download](https://ollama.com/download/Ollama.dmg) ### Windows [Download](https://ollama.com/download/OllamaSetup.exe) ### Linux ```shell curl -fsSL https://ollama.com/install.sh | sh ``` [Manual install instructions](https://github.com/ollama/ollama/blob/main/docs/linux.md) ### Docker The official [Ollama Docker image](https://hub.docker.com/r/ollama/ollama) `ollama/ollama` is available on Docker Hub. ### Libraries - [ollama-python](https://github.com/ollama/ollama-python) - [ollama-js](https://github.com/ollama/ollama-js) ### Community - [Discord](https://discord.gg/ollama) - [Reddit](https://reddit.com/r/ollama) ## Quickstart To run and chat with [Gemma 3](https://ollama.com/library/gemma3): ```shell ollama run gemma3 ``` ## Model library Ollama supports a list of models available on [ollama.com/library](https://ollama.com/library 'ollama model library') Here are some example models that can be downloaded: | Model | Parameters | Size | Download | | ------------------ | ---------- | ----- | -------------------------------- | | Gemma 3 | 1B | 815MB | `ollama run gemma3:1b` | | Gemma 3 | 4B | 3.3GB | `ollama run gemma3` | | Gemma 3 | 12B | 8.1GB | `ollama run gemma3:12b` | | Gemma 3 | 27B | 17GB | `ollama run gemma3:27b` | | QwQ | 32B | 20GB | `ollama run qwq` | | DeepSeek-R1 | 7B | 4.7GB | `ollama run deepseek-r1` | | DeepSeek-R1 | 671B | 404GB | `ollama run deepseek-r1:671b` | | Llama 4 | 109B | 67GB | `ollama run llama4:scout` | | Llam

## freeCodeCamp.org's open-source codebase and curriculum

[freeCodeCamp.org](https://www.freecodecamp.org) is a friendly community where you can learn to code for free. It is run by a [donor-supported 501(c)(3) charity](https://www.freecodecamp.org/donate) to help millions of busy adults transition into tech. Our community has already helped more than 100,000 people get their first developer job.

Our full-stack web development and machine learning curriculum is completely free and self-paced. We have thousands of interactive coding challenges to help you expand your skills.

## Table of Contents

- [Certifications](#certifications)
- [The Learning Platform](#the-learning-platform)
- [Reporting Bugs and Issues](#reporting-bugs-and-issues)
- [Reporting Security Issues and Responsible Disclosure](#reporting-security-issues-and-responsible-disclosure)
- [Contributing](#contributing)
- [Platform, Build and Deployment Status](#platform-build-and-deployment-status)
- [License](#license)

### Certifications

freeCodeCamp.org offers several free developer certifications. Each of these certifications involves building 5 required web app projects, along with hundreds of optional coding challenges to help you prepare for those projects. We estimate that each certification will take a beginner programmer around 300 hours t

sources.name: facebook/react
sources.readme_snippet:
# [React](https://react.dev/) · [![GitHub license](https://img.shields.io/badge/license-MIT-blue.svg)](https://github.com/facebook/react/blob/main/LICENSE) [![npm version](https://img.shields.io/npm/v/react.svg?style=flat)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/react) [![(Runtime) Build and Test](https://github.com/facebook/react/actions/workflows/runtime_build_and_test.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/facebook/react/actions/workflows/runtime_build_and_test.yml) [![(Compiler) TypeScript](https://github.com/facebook/react/actions/workflows/compiler_typescript.yml/badge.svg?branch=main)](https://github.com/facebook/react/actions/workflows/compiler_typescript.yml) [![PRs Welcome](https://img.shields.io/badge/PRs-welcome-brightgreen.svg)](https://legacy.reactjs.org/docs/how-to-contribute.html#your-first-pull-request)

React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces.

* **Declarative:** React makes it painless to create interactive UIs. Design simple views for each state in your application, and React will efficiently update and render just the right components when your data changes. Declarative views make your code more predictable, simpler to understand, and easier to debug.
* **Component-Based:** Build encapsulated components that manage their own state, then compose them to make complex UIs. Since component logic is written in JavaScript instead of templates, you can easily pass rich data through your app and keep the state out of the DOM.
* **Learn Once, Write Anywhere:** We don't make assumptions about the rest of your technology stack, so you can develop new features in React without rewriting existing code. React can also render on the server using [Node](https://nodejs.org/en) and power mobile apps using [React Native](https://reactnative.dev/).

[Learn how to use React in your project](https://react.dev/learn).

## Installation

React has been designed for gradual adoption from the start, and **you can use as little or as much React as you need**:

sources.name: harness/harness
sources.readme_snippet:
# Harness
Harness Open Source is an open source development platform packed with the power of code hosting, automated DevOps pipelines, hosted development environments (Gitspaces), and artifact registries.

## Overview
Harness Open source is an open source development platform packed with the power of code hosting, automated DevOps pipelines, Gitspaces, and artifact registries.


## Running Harness locally
> The latest publicly released docker image can be found on [harness/harness](https://hub.docker.com/r/harness/harness).

To install Harness yourself, simply run the command below. Once the container is up, you can visit http://localhost:3000 in your browser.

```bash
docker run -d \
  -p 3000:3000 \
  -p 3022:3022 \
  -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock \
  -v /tmp/harness:/data \
  --name harness \
  --restart always \
  harness/harness
```
> The Harness image uses a volume to store the database and repositories. It is highly recommended to use a bind mount or named volume as otherwise all data will be lost once the container is stopped.

See [developer.harness.io](https://developer.harness.io/docs/open-source) to learn how to get the most out of Harness.

## Where is Drone?

Harness Open Source represents a massive investment in the next generation of Drone. Where Drone focused solely on continuous integration, Harness adds source code hosting, developer environments (gitspaces), and artifact registries; providing teams with an end-to-end, open source DevOps platform.

The goal is for Harness to eventually be at full parity with Drone in terms of pipeline capabilities, allowing users to seamlessly migrate from Drone to Harness.

But, we expect this to take some time, which is why we took a snapshot of Drone as a feature branch [drone](https://github.com/harness/harness/tree/drone) ([README](https://github.com/harness/harness/blob/drone/.github/readme.md)) so it can continue development.

As for Harness, the development is taking place on the [main](htt

sources.readme_snippet:
Special thanks to:

Warp, built for coding with multiple AI agents
Available for macOS, Linux and Windows


LosslessCut

The swiss army knife of lossless video/audio editing


Thanks to my supporters and everyone who purchased LosslessCut!



LosslessCut aims to be the ultimate cross platform FFmpeg GUI for extremely fast and lossless operations on video, audio, subtitle and other related media files. The main feature is lossless trimming and cutting of video and audio files, which is great for saving space by rough-cutting your large video files taken from a video camera, GoPro, drone, etc. It lets you quickly extract the good parts from your videos and discard many gigabytes of data without doing a slow re-encode and thereby losing quality. sources.readme_snippet:
# JavaScript Algorithms and Data Structures

> ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ UKRAINE [IS BEING ATTACKED](https://war.ukraine.ua/) BY RUSSIAN ARMY. CIVILIANS ARE GETTING KILLED. RESIDENTIAL AREAS ARE GETTING BOMBED.
> - Help Ukraine via:
>   - [Serhiy Prytula Charity Foundation](https://prytulafoundation.org/en/)
>   - [Come Back Alive Charity Foundation](https://savelife.in.ua/en/donate-en/)
>   - [National Bank of Ukraine](https://bank.gov.ua/en/news/all/natsionalniy-bank-vidkriv-spetsrahunok-dlya-zboru-koshtiv-na-potrebi-armiyi)
> - More info on [war.ukraine.ua](https://war.ukraine.ua/) and [MFA of Ukraine](https://twitter.com/MFA_Ukraine)

<hr/>

[![CI](https://github.com/trekhleb/javascript-algorithms/workflows/CI/badge.svg)](https://github.com/trekhleb/javascript-algorithms/actions?query=workflow%3ACI+branch%3Amaster)
[![codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/trekhleb/javascript-algorithms/branch/master/graph/badge.svg)](https://codecov.io/gh/trekhleb/javascript-algorithms)
![repo size](https://img.shields.io/github/repo-size/trekhleb/javascript-algorithms.svg)

This repository contains JavaScript based examples of many
popular algorithms and data structures.

Each algorithm and data structure has its own separate README
with related explanations and links for further reading (including ones
to YouTube videos).

_Read this in other languages:_

## Data Structures

A data structure is a particular way of organizing and storing data in a computer so that it can
be access

sources.name: huginn/huginn
sources.readme_snippet:
![Huginn](https://raw.github.com/huginn/huginn/master/media/huginn-logo.png "Your agents are standing by.")

-----

## What is Huginn?

Huginn is a system for building agents that perform automated tasks for you online.  They can read the web, watch for events, and take actions on your behalf.  Huginn's Agents create and consume events, propagating them along a directed graph.  Think of it as a hackable version of IFTTT or Zapier on your own server.  You always know who has your data.  You do.

![the origin of the name](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/huginn/huginn/master/doc/imgs/the-name.png)

#### Here are some of the things that you can do with Huginn:

* Track the weather and get an email when it's going to rain (or snow) tomorrow ("Don't forget your umbrella!")
* List terms that you care about and receive email when their occurrence on Twitter changes.  (For example, want to know when something interesting has happened in the world of Machine Learning?  Huginn will watch the term "machine learning" on Twitter and tell you when there is a spike in discussion.)
* Watch for air travel or shopping deals
* Follow your project names on Twitter and get updates when people mention them
* Scrape websites and receive email when they change
* Connect to Adioso, HipChat, FTP, IMAP, Jabber, JIRA, MQTT, nextbus, Pushbullet, Pushover, RSS, Bash, Slack, StubHub, translation APIs, Twilio, Twitter, and Weibo, to name a few.
* Send digest email with things that you care about at specific times during the day
* Track counts of high frequency events and send an SMS within moments when they spike, such as the term "san francisco emergency"
* Send and receive WebHooks
* Run custom JavaScript or CoffeeScript functions
* Track your location over time
* Create Amazon Mechanical Turk workflows as the inputs, or outputs, of agents (the Amazon Turk Agent is called the "HumanTaskAgent"). For example: "Once a day, ask 5 people for a funny cat photo; send the results to 5 more people to be

why_it_works: Novelty + Health + Author signals + Semantic relevance elevate hidden gems.
Diversity bonus avoids conceptual duplicates when embeddings are enabled.
Permissive licensing keeps integration safe and fast.
